def: something that is unusual or unexpected
sent: The student’s poor performance on the latest test was an anomaly since she had previously earned excellent grades.

def: not easily understood or explained
sent: Politicians have been known to provide equivocal answers to reporters’ questions.

def: very clear and easy to understand
sent: The lecture was lucid and straightforward, allowing the students to fully grasp the concepts presented.

def: to cause (something) to happen quickly or suddenly
sent: Unforeseen costs can precipitate a budget crisis

def: to make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense
sent: A massage can assuage the soreness in your muscles.

def: having or showing great knowledge
sent: High school students often struggle with novels that are more erudite than they are entertaining.

def: wastefully extravagant
sent: The prodigal prince bought lavish gifts and planned expensive events.

def: a person or thing that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand
sent: Scientists continue to research cancer to solve the enigmaof its primary cause, which will hopefully lead to a cure.

def: intensely enthusiastic or passionate
sent: The child showed a fervid fascination for superheroes, pouring over comic books for hours.

def: a willingness to take bold risks / adj. –  showing a lack of respect
sent: The new CEO pursued audacious initiatives to save the company from bankruptcy. / The student’s audaciousremark earned her a seat in afternoon detention.

def: remove the moisture from (something)
sent: The heat and energy from the sun can desiccate even the most hearty plants

def: deserving praise and commendation
sent: Providing affordable healthcare for all citizens is a laudablegoal.

def: a person who makes an excessive display of learning
sent: Professor Blackwell, a well-known pedant, required his pre-med students to speak in Latin throughout the entire semester.

def: to waver between different opinions or actions
sent: Undergraduate students often vacillate among various majors before deciding which degree to pursue.

def: to make (something) impure or weaker by adding something of inferior quality
sent: Many chefs use fresh produce and refuse to adulteratetheir dishes with canned ingredients.

def: given to sudden changes of mood or behavior
sent: The capricious supervisor would hand out raises one day and fire his entire staff the next.

def: to produce, cause, or give rise to (something)
sent: Political debates can engender controversy regarding the subjects discussed.

def: tending to talk a great deal
sent: The loquacious professor was known for his five-hour lectures.

def: dealing with the problems that exist in a reasonable and logical way instead of depending on theories
sent: A pragmatic approach to legislation can be difficult given the complexities of politics.

def: likely to change rapidly and unpredictably
sent: It is possible for a country’s political climate to remain volatile for decades.

def: to confirm or make more certain
sent: The scientist was able to corroborate his hypothesis with data gathered from multiple sources.

def: lasting for a very short time
sent: An ephemeral moment of victory may last mere seconds, but it can remain as a triumphant memory for decades.

def: using few words
sent: The student’s laconic response suggested  that she did not know very much about the topic the professor was discussing.

def: the state or quality of being correct or proper
sent: The students were instructed to behave with the utmost propriety while on their class field trip.

def: a harsh, unpleasant mixture of sounds
sent: The cacophony of the middle school band warming up was nearly unbearable for the audience.

def: cause (someone or something) to feel drained of energy; weaken
sent: The boxer used a swift left uppercut to the jaw to enervatehis opponent.

def: a person who dislikes humankind
sent: The neighborhood misanthrope surrounded his yard with barbed wire to keep people away.

def: regard with great respect
sent: To venerate the fire chief’s forty years of service, the department held a special banquet.

def: to express contempt for; ridicule
sent: The unreasonable supervise was known to deride his employees on a daily basis.

def: stubbornly refusing to change one’s opinion
sent: The obdurate three-year-old refused to eat any vegetables, no matter how they were prepared.

def: a lack of harmony or agreement
sent: The school board’s meeting lasted for hours due to the length debate fueled by dissonance among opinions.

def: excessively talkative
sent: The garrulous hair stylist talked to each customer for hours at a time.

def: excessive display of wealth
sent: Owning a mansion doesn’t imply ostentation, but traveling exclusively by private jet certainly can.

def: avoid telling the truth by not directly answering a question
sent: During the trial, the lead witness was willing to prevaricatein order to protect his friend.

def: a thing formed or added by gradual growth or increase.
sent: The city has a historic core surrounded by recent accretions.

def: the pursuit of pleasure; sensual self-indulgence.
sent: She was a perfect specimen of selfish hedonism.

def: a remedy for all ills or difficulties / cure-all
sent: The law will improve the lives of local farmers, but it is no panacea.

def: affectedly dainty or delicate
sent: She took mincing steps.

def: to become diffused throughout every part of
sent: A feeling of great sadness pervades the film.

def: to reduce in vigor or intensity or impurities. ALSO to make improvement by introducing subtleties or distinctions.
sent: The inventor of the machine spent years refining the design.

def: affected by strong feelings of love, admiration, or fascination
sent: Japanese fans took to the gruff Americans, but the homegrown players were less enamored.

def: the act of blaming or condemning sternly or reprimanding
sent: The country faces international censure for its alleged involvement in the assassination.

def: to voice disapproval of
sent: Without exception, book reviewers reprehended the novel's tired plot.

def: mental acceptance as true or real
sent: Some members of my family give credence to gossip.

def: outwardly similar or corresponding to something without having its genuine qualities, deceitful
sent: The spurious eminence of the pop celebrity was revealed by the lackluster Spotify listens.

def: an extremely confused, complicated, or embarrassing situation.
sent: California considers the 2016 Election to be America's imbroglio.

def: involved with others in an illegal activity or wrongdoing.
sent: All of these people are complicit in some criminal conspiracy.

def: rapid increase in numbers.
sent: "You left the raw chicken out. Thank of the proliferation of salmonella!"

def: the action or practice of acting as if one were morally superior to other people.
sent: They have no shame and turn on the phony sanctimony

def: criticize in an abusive or angrily insulting manner.
sent: "After the impeachment, Bill Clinton is now reviled by the party that he had helped to lead."

def: entertain or amuse (someone) with talk / lavishly supply (someone) with food or drink.
sent: Ariel regaled everyone at her Sweet 16 party.

def: (of a person or their behavior) primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics.
sent: Insurance premiums are very very high for mercenaries.

def: (of a phrase or idea) lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.
sent: Some teachers give you an auto-F if you include any cliches or a hackneyed thesis.

def: friendly and cheerful.
sent: Kerry is constantly genial, welcoming everyone with a smile and big hello.

def: having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
sent: It's very hard for me to be friends with someone who is irascible and not getting help.

def: friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
sent: Esther's affable nature is the first thing that I notice in the dining hall.

def: bad-tempered or irritable.
sent: I am most choleric when I feel sick from anxiety.

def: quiet, gentle, and easily imposed on; submissive.
sent: "I used to call her Miss Mouse because she was so meek and mild"

def: (especially of fabric) light, delicate, and translucent.
sent: A diaphanous dress of pale gold draped the woman on the Paris catwalk.

def: deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected.
sent: Smith College has an anomalous student culture.

def: overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style / exaggerated dramatic behavior designed to attract attention.
sent: Histrionic people want attention but I can't stop thinking about how much of my time they're wasting.

def: (of a person) having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition.
sent: My dad is extremely phlegmatic, even outside of pollen season.

def: (of a person) tending to show feelings, especially of affection, openly. conclusive evidence.
sent: Many love songs are over-the-top demonstrative.

def: showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense.
sent: Forrest Gump had vehement love and dedication to Jenny.

def: excessively sweet or sentimental.
sent: I wrote a saccharine jar of comliments. I almost regret it.

def: to bring into discord or conflict; involve in contention or strife / to throw into confusion; complicate.
sent: Group work during summer linear algebra day 2 was embroiling.

def: a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.
sent: You get a eulogy if you die but a encomium if you're still kicking.

def: a public speech or published text in praise of someone or something.
sent: A NYT panegyric on friendship was heartwarming to many childhood buddies.

def: the dwelling of a hermit, especially when small and remote.
sent: If I live in Los Angeles after college, I'll live with my mom or my own hermitage.
